The DNC's voter file is considered the party's most sensitive information, and the cyber age has changed elections forever, with many systems vulnerable to manipulation. Rob Joyce, former White House cybersecurity coordinator, warned that the focus has shifted from stealing secrets to imposing national power through cyber attacks. Microsoft has detected hackers linked to Russian intelligence targeting the Senate and think tanks, and Facebook has uncovered other disinformation efforts aimed at disrupting the midterms. CNN reported that the DNC initially feared a real hacking attempt but later determined it was a simulated phishing test. Despite this, the DNC and the two companies involved remain vigilant and believe they thwarted a potential attack. The DNC's voter file is a target due to its sensitivity, and the incident highlights the need for continued vigilance in protecting election systems from cyber threats.</s>

answers: Another fatality in the Boston bombings has been identified: The family of 29-year-old Krystle Campbell says she was killed as she and a friend were cheering on another friend who was racing, reports WCVB. "This is just a waste," says her mother. “Everyone that knew her loved her. She was always smiling. You couldn’t ask for a better daughter. She was the best.” Campbell was a restaurant manager, reports the Boston Herald, which notes an especially wrenching detail: Her father was initially told she was alive, but when he got to the ICU, he realized it was his daughter's friend who had survived. Campbell is the second of the three people killed to be identified. The first was 8-year-old Martin Richard, and his father, Bill, released a statement today thanking supporters and asking for privacy, reports WBZ. "My dear son Martin has died from injuries sustained in the attack on Boston. My wife and daughter are both recovering from serious injuries. We thank our family and friends, those we know and those we have never met, for their thoughts and prayers. I ask that you continue to pray for my family as we remember Martin. We also ask for your patience and for privacy as we work to simultaneously grieve and recover. Thank you." The third victim was a grad student at Boston University, but the person's identity is being withheld until the family says it's OK to release, reports USA Today.
response: On Monday, three people were killed and over 100 were injured when two bombs went off near the finish line of the Boston Marathon. The victims included an 8-year-old boy, Krystle Campbell, 29, and Martin Richard, 8. The bombings also injured Campbell's father and another person, who were hospitalized. The third victim has not been identified. The police have said there are no known additional threats following the bombings and have promised to make sure the city pulls together. The FBI is also investigating. Meanwhile, a medical student from China who was watching the race with two friends near the finish line was identified as the third victim by the Chinese Consulate in New York. In response to the tragedy, President Obama has praised first responders and others who helped the injured, and Pope Francis has sent a message expressing his condolences. The city of Boston has shown strength, compassion, and determination to see justice done, according to the district attorney. </s>

answers: There are more obese or overweight people in the world today than there were people of any weight in 1935, the most comprehensive look at worldwide obesity in decades warns. The 188-country study found that there are 2.1 billion overweight or obese people in the world, making up around 30% of the world's population, up from 20% in 1980, USA Today reports. Not a single country has recorded a decline in obesity over the last 30 years. "We hoped there would be some examples of success that you could latch onto," a study co-author says. "But there's a complete lack of success stories in bringing down obesity." The study published in British medical journal the Lancet found that the Middle East and north Africa had seen the biggest weight gains, though the US still has the largest number of obese people, with 87 million of the world's 671 million obese people, reports Reuters. Other countries, however, have even higher obesity rates, including Tonga, where more than 50% of all adults are obese. "Two-thirds of the obese population actually resides in developing countries," says one of the researchers; they warn that obesity rates are rising among rich and poor countries, men and women, and adults and children alike.
response:
Obesity is a major public health concern globally, with nearly one-third of the world's population classified as either obese or overweight. According to a new study published in the Lancet medical journal, the number of obese people worldwide has increased from 857 million in 1980 to 2.1 billion in 2013, with the highest rates seen in developing countries. The study found that obesity rates are rising faster in developing countries than in developed countries, with more than half of the world's obese population living in just 10 countries, including the United States, China, India, Russia, Brazil, Mexico, Egypt, Germany, Pakistan, and Indonesia. The researchers also found that obesity is a complex problem fueled by the availability of cheap, unhealthy foods and sedentary lifestyles, and that it is a major risk factor for heart disease, stroke, diabetes, arthritis, and certain cancers. In response to the growing obesity epidemic, the World Health Organization launched a commission this month to study rising obesity among children worldwide and suggest solutions.

answers: It's been a year since Katie Holmes filed for divorce from Tom Cruise, and apparently Cruise is feeling sentimental. A source tells UK magazine Look the actor sent Holmes an "emotional letter" looking to, at the very least, be friends again, Australia's News Network reports. "It's like he's finally recognized that Katie will always be the love of his life," the source says. Even so, "It won't have been an over the top letter—it has been a year and I'm sure Tom will have been aware that Katie wouldn't be interested in running straight back into his arms." Sources close to Holmes say she was "touched" by the letter, which doesn't sound promising for Cruise. "Tom would no doubt take her back in a second, but I don't think that's what Katie wants," says one. response:

answers: The investigation into the mysterious deaths of a billionaire and his wife is now being led by homicide detectives, police say—suggesting the deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman were either murder-suicide or a double murder. Police, who have described the deaths as "suspicious," revealed Sunday that the cause of death for both Shermans was "ligature neck compression," a form of strangulation, the CBC reports. Sources have told the media that the couple were found hanging near an indoor pool in the basement of their Toronto mansion. Police say they haven't found any sign of forced entry, or a note that could explain what happened to 75-year-old pharmaceutical tycoon Barry Sherman and his 70-year-old wife, both renowned philanthropists. The couple's four children have rejected what they say are "rumors" that the deaths are being investigated as a murder-suicide, and many of the influential couple's friends agree. "There is absolutely zero debate in my mind, this was a double homicide," says Canadian Sen. Linda Frum, a longtime friend of the couple, per the New York Times. The Globe and Mail reports that just days before the bodies were found, Honey Sherman was enthusiastically making plans for their annual trip to Florida, emailing friends that she would be traveling to the state on Dec. 18 and Barry Sherman would join her a week later. The couple also sent out invitations last week to a dinner party at their winter home in Palm Beach.
response: Barry and Honey Sherman, a wealthy Canadian couple, were found dead in their Toronto mansion on Friday. The cause of death was determined to be ligature neck compression, and the police have classified the case as "suspicious" but have not confirmed it as a murder-suicide. The couple was well-known in the community for their philanthropy and business ventures, including Apotex Inc., a generic pharmaceutical company worth billions of dollars. The investigation is ongoing, and police have not identified any suspects or found any signs of forced entry. Friends and colleagues of the couple have expressed shock and disbelief at the news, describing them as kind and generous people. A memorial service has been held for the couple, and they will be remembered for their contributions to the community and their passion for life.</s>

answers: The final round of voting began in Egypt today, and it looks like the Muslim Brotherhood could walk off with a controlling majority of seats in Parliament's lower house. The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, the country's mainstream Islamist party, had already won a high percentage of the seats awarded in the first and second rounds of voting. Two of the nine provinces voting today are Brotherhood strongholds, where some of the party's most well-known candidates are running, the New York Times reports. A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far. Also today, prosecutors began presenting their case against former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Bloomberg notes. His trial resumed last week after a two-month break; state TV today showed Mubarak being carried to and from the courtroom on a gurney. "He deserves an end of humiliation and indignity," said the chief prosecutor, according to the AP.
response:
The current news highlights Egypt's ongoing political developments and the trial of former President Hosni Mubarak.


1. In the third and final round of parliamentary elections, Egyptians returned to the polls as the Muslim Brotherhood sought to consolidate its gains and win a majority of the seats. The Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice party has already secured a significant percentage of the seats allocated by party voting and individual candidates.




















2. Former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's trial resumed after a two-month hiatus, with the prosecutor accusing him of imposing "tyrannical rule" and dedicating the last 10 years of his reign to ensuring his son, Gamal, would succeed him. Mubarak is charged with complicity in the killing of over 800 protesters during the popular uprising that forced him from power.

answers: Police in Vermont say a car ended up almost vertical when the driver swerved quickly in response to her GPS ordering her to "turn around." The car was suspended almost vertically on guide wires attached to a utility pole (see a photo here) in Mendon on Wednesday night, reports the AP. Police say 30-year-old Nabila Altahan of Dorchester, Mass., was headed west on US Route 4 when she passed her intended destination and reacted quickly to the instructions, leaving the road at a significant enough speed to propel the vehicle up the wires. She wasn't injured. (This driver followed her GPS into a lake.)
response: On Wednesday evening in Mendon, Vermont, a car became suspended from a telephone guy wire after the driver reacted too quickly to a GPS unit's instructions to turn around. According to police, the driver, Nabila Altahan, reacted too quickly to the GPS system's directions, causing the car to leave the road and end up suspended on the guy wire. Luckily, Altahan and her passenger were not injured in the incident. Witnesses reported seeing Altahan jump out of the car as it was suspended from the pole. State police and the Rutland City Fire Department responded to the scene, which was near a miniature golf course. This incident highlights the potential dangers of relying too heavily on GPS systems and the importance of remaining vigilant while driving.  </s>
